revision.comment: In Catholicism (and other religions) a "see" is part of a metropolis but is much different, nonetheless
revision.text:
An '''episcopal see''' ([[Latin]]: ''episcopalis sedes'') is, in the original sense, the official ''seat'' of a [[bishop]]. This seat, which is also referred to as the bishop's [[cathedra]], is placed in the bishop's principal church, which is therefore called the bishop's [[cathedral]].<ref name=ODCC>The Oxford Dictionary of the Christian Church (Oxford University Press 2005, ISBN 978-0-19-280290-3), s.v. ''see''</ref> The seat is also called the bishop's ''throne'', especially in the Eastern Orthodox Church.<ref>For instance, [http://www.ec-patr.org/docdisplay.php?lang=en&id=825&tla=en Communiqué of the Ecumenical Patriarchate]</ref>
The term is also used of the town or place where the cathedral is located,<ref name=ODCC/> giving rise to expressions such as "the Episcopal See of Gibraltar".<ref>[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1876/aug/12/church-of-england-episcopal-see-of Hansard report]</ref>
The bishop's seat is the earliest symbol of bishop's authority,<ref name=ODCC/> and the word "see" is thus often applied to the area over which the bishop exercises authority. This usually corresponds to a [[diocese]], as in the expression "within the see of Ebbsfleet"<ref>[http://www.ebbsfleet.org.uk/congcoun.htm The Lay Council and Congress of the See of Ebbsfleet]</ref> and "built within the see of the bishop of Worcester".<ref>[http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=36472 Priory of Little Malvern]</ref> But it is sometimes given a wider significance, referring for instance to an area under [[patriarch]]al authority.<ref>[http://ecole.evansville.edu/articles/crete.html Christianity in Crete (to 827)]</ref>
In common English usage, the term ''[[Holy See]]'' most often refers to the episcopal see of the [[Bishop of Rome]].
